deregulation in the telecommunications industry has had many consequences, both positive and negative. here are some of the main effects:

positive consequences:
- increased competition: deregulation has increased competition in the telecommunications industry. this has led to lower prices, better quality of service, and more options for consumers.
- innovation: deregulation has encouraged innovation and new technologies in the telecommunications industry. this has led to the development of new products and services, such as mobile phones, broadband internet, and digital tv.
- investment: deregulation has attracted more investment to the telecommunications industry, as companies are more willing to invest in a market with fewer regulations.

negative consequences:
- consolidation: deregulation has led to consolidation in the telecommunications industry, as larger companies acquire smaller competitors. this has reduced competition and can lead to higher prices and reduced choice for consumers.
- system issues: deregulation has led to issues with the system because the government cannot intervene if there is a lack of service or issues related to service provided by private companies in most cases.
- suboptimal allocation of resources: deregulation has also led to suboptimal allocation of resources, as companies focus on serving high-density urban areas to maximize profits, leaving rural areas behind.

these are some of the consequences of deregulation in the telecommunications industry. overall, depending on the specific case, deregulation can have both positive and negative impacts.
